editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Mad world, my masters.

div.p: As it hath been lately in action by the children of Paul's.
London, printed by H. B. for Walter Burre, and are to be sold in Paul's churchyard, at the sign of the crane. 1608.

div.stage: Enter Dick Folly-wit, and his consorts, lieutenant mawe-worme, ancient hoboy, and others his comrades.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Captain, regent, principal,

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: What shall I call thee?
The noble spark of bounty;
The lifeblood of society.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Call me your forecast, you whoresons, when you come drunk out of a tavern, 'tis I must cast your plots into form still; 'tis I must manage the prank, or I'll not give a louse for the proceeding: I must let fly my civil fortunes, turn wildbrain, lay my wits upo'the tenters, you rascals, to maintain a company of villains, whom I love in my very soul and conscience.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A ha, our little forecast.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Hang you, you have bewitched me among you, I was as well given till I fell to be wicked, my grandsire had hope of me, I went all in black, swore but a Sundaies, never came home drunk, but upon fasting nights to cleanse my stomach; 'slid now I'm quite altered, blown into light colours, let out oaths by'th minute, sit up late till it be early, drink drunk till I am sober, sink down dead in a tavern, and rise in a tobacco-shop: here's a transformation: I was wont yet to pity the simple, and leave 'em some money: 'slid, now I gull 'em without conscience; I go without order, swear without number, gull without mercy, and drink without measure.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I deny the last, for if you drink never so much, you drink within measure.

sp.speaker: Folly-w
sp.p: How prove you that sir?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Because the drawers never fill their pots.

sp.speaker: Folly-w
sp.p: Mass that was well found out all drunkards may lawfully say, they drink within measure by that trick, dna now I'm put i'th mind of a trick can you keep your countenance villains? yet I am a fool to ask that, for how can they keep their countenance that have lost their credits?

sp.speaker: Ants.
sp.p: I warrant you for blushing captain.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: I easily believe that ancient, for thou lost thy colours once; nay faith as for blushing, I think there's grace little enough amongst you all, 'tis lent in your cheeks, the flag's down; well, your blushing face I suspect not, nor indeed greatly your laughing-face, unless you had more money in your purses: then thus compendiously now, you all know the possibilities of my hereafter fortunes, and the humour of my frolic grandsire sir bounteous progress; whose death makes all possible to me: I shall have all, when he has nothing; but now he has all, I shall have nothing: I think one mind runs through a million of 'em; they love to keep us sober all the while they're alive, that when they're dead we may drink to their healths; they cannot abide to see us merry all the while there above ground; and that makes so many laugh at their father's funerals: I know my grandsire has his will in a box, and has bequeathed all to me, when he can carry nothing away; but stood I in need of poor ten pounds now, by his will I should hang my self ere I should get it, there's no such word in his will I warrant you, nor no such thought in his mind.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: You may build upon that captain.

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p:
Then since he has no will to do me good as long as he lives; by mine own will, I'll do myself good before he dies, and now I arrive at the purpose. You are not ignorant I'm sure, you true and necessary implements of mischief; first, that my grandsire sir bounteous progress is a knight of thousands, and therefore no knight since one
thousand six hundred: next, that he keeps a house like his name bounteous, open for all comers: thirdly and lastly, that he stands much upon the glory of his compliment, variety of entertainment, together with the largeness of his kitchen, longitude of his buttery, and fecundity of his larder, and thinks himself never happier than when some stiff l. or great countess alights, to make light his dishes: these being well mixed together may give my project better encouragement, and make my purpose spring forth more fortunate: to be short, and cut off a great deal of dirty way; I'll down to my grandsire like a l.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: How captain?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A French ruff, a thin beard, and a strong perfume will do't: I can hire blue coats for you all by Westminster clock, and that colour will be soonest believed.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: But prithee captain?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Push, I reach passed your fathoms; you desire crowns.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: From the crown of our head, to the sole of our foot bully.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Why carry yourselves but probably, and carry away enough with yourselves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why there spoke a Roman captain, m. penitent brothel.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Sweet m. Folly-wit ..

Here's a mad brain a'th first, whose pranks scorn to have presidents; to be second to any; or walk beneath any: madcaps inventions, has played more tricks than the cards can allow a man, and of the last stamp too, hating imitation, a fellow, whose only glory is to be prime of the company; to be sure of which, he maintains all the rest: he's the carrion, and they the kites that gorge upon him.
sp.l: But why in others do I check wild passions,
And retain deadly follies in myself?
I tax his youth of common received riot,
Times comic flashes, and the fruits of blood;
and in myself sooth up adulterous motions,
And such an appetite that I know dams me,
Yet willingly embrace it, love to Harebrains wife,
Over whose hours and pleasures her sick husband
With a fantastic but deserved suspect,
Bestows his serious time in watch and ward;
And therefore I'm constrained to use the means
Of one that knows no mean, a courtesan,
One poison for another, whom her husband
Without suspicion innocently admits
Into her company, who with tried art
Corrupts and loosens her most constant powers,
Making his jealousy more than half a wittol,
Before his face plotting his own abuse,
To which himself gives aim.
Whilst the broad arrow with the forked head
Misses his brow but narrowly; see here she comes,
The close courtesan, whose mother is her bawd.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Master penitent brothel.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: My little pretty lady gull-man, the news, the comfort?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: You're the fortunate man sir, knight a'th holland skirt: there wants but opportunity and she's wax of your own fashioning, she had wrought herself into the form of your love before my art set finger to her.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Did our affections meet? our thoughts keep time?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: So it should seem by the music, the only jar is in the grumbling base viol her husband.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: O his waking suspicion!

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Sigh not m. penitent, trust the managing of the business with me, 'tis for my credit now to see't well finished: if I do you no good sir, you shall give me no money sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I am arrived at the court of conscience; a courtesan! O admirable times! honesty is removed to the common place. Farewell lady.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: How now daughter?

sp.speaker: Curtiz,
sp.p: What news mother?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: A token from thy keeper.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: O from sir bounteous progress: he's my keeper in deed, but there's many a piece of venison stolen that my keeper wots not on; there's no park kept so warily, but loses flesh one time or other; and no woman kept so privately, but may watch advantage to make the best of her pleasure: and in common reason one keeper cannot be enough for so proud a park as a woman.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Hold thee there girl.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Fear not me mother.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Every part of the world shoots up daily into more subtlety: the very spider weaves her cawls with more art and cunning, to entrap the fly.
sp.l: The shallow ploughman can distinguish now,
Twixt simple truth and a dissembling brow.
Your base mechanic fellow can spy out
A weakness in a l. and learns to flout.
How dost behoove us then that live by sleight,
To have our wits wound up to their stretched height?
Fifteen times thou knowest I have sold thy maidenhead ,
To make up a dowry for thy marriage, and yet
There's maidenhead enough for old sir bounteous still,
He'll be all his life time about it yet, and be as far to seek when he has done.
The sums that I have told upon thy pillow!
I shall once see those golden days again:
Though fifteen, all thy may den heads are not gone:
The Italian is not served yet, nor the French:
The British men come for a dozen at once,
They engross all the market, tut my girl,
'Tis nothing but a politic conveyance;
A sincere carriage, a religious eyebrow
That throws their charms over the worldlings senses;
And when thou spiest a fool that truly pities
The false springs of thine eyes,
and honourably dotes upon thy love,
If he be rich, set him by for a husband;
Be wisely tempered and learn this my wench
Who gets th' opinion for a virtuous name
May sin at pleasure, and ne'er think of shame:

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Mother I am too deep a scholar grown to learn my first rules now.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: 'Twill be thy own, I say no more; peace, hark, remove thyself, o, the two elder brothers.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: A fair hour sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Good morrow gentlemen, master inesse, and m. possibility.

sp.speaker: Esse
sp.p: Where's the little sweet lady your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Even at her book sir.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: So religious?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: 'Tis no new motion sir, sh'as took it from an infant.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: May we deserve a sight of her, lady?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Upon that condition you will promise me gentlemen, to avoid all profane talk, wanton compliments, undecent phrases, and lascivious courtings ▪ (Which I know my daughter will sooner die than endure,) I am contented your suits shall be granted.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: Not a bawdy syllable I protest.

sp.speaker: Inesse.
sp.p: Syllable was placest there, for indeed your one syllables are your bawdiest words, prick that down.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She may make nightwork on't, 'twas well recovered, he cats and courtesans stroll most i'th night, her friend may be received and conveyed forth, nightly, he be at charge for watch and ward, for watch and ward i'faith, and here they come.

sp.speaker: First,
sp.p: Give your worship good even.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Welcome my friends, I must deserve your diligence in an employment serious: the troth is, there is a cunning plot laid, but happily discovered, to rob my house: the night uncertain when, but fixed within the circle of this month: nor does this villainy consist in numbers:
sp.l: Or many partners, only some one
Shall in the form of my familiar friend,
Be received privately into my house,
By some perfidious servant of mine own,
Addressed fit for the practice.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: O abominable!

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: If you be faithful watchmen, show your goodness, and with these angel's shore up your eyelids: let me not be purloined, purloined indeed; the merry Greeks conceive me: there is a gem I would not lose, kept by the Italian under lock and key: we English men are careless creatures: well, I have said enough.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: And we will do enough sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Why well said, watch me a good turn now, so, so, so,
Rise villainy with the lark, why 'tis prevented,
Or steal't by with the leather winged bat:
sp.p: The evening cannot save it, peace; o lady Gulman, my wife's only company! welcome; and how does the virtuous matron, that good old gentlewoman thy mother? I persuade myself, if modesty be in the world she has part on't: a woman of an excellent carriage all her life time, in court, city, and country.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Sha's always carried it well in those places sir; witness three bastards a piece: how does your sweet bedfellow sir? you see I'm her boldest visitant.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And welcome sweet virgin, the only companion, my soul wishes for her; I left her within at her lute, prithee give her good counsel.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Alas, she needs none sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Yet, yet, yet, a little of thy instructions will not come amiss to her.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: I'll bestow my labour sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Do, labour her prithee; I have conveyed away all her wanton pamphlets, as hero and Leander, Venus and Adonis, o two luscious marrowbone pies for a young married wife, here, here, prithee take the resolution, and read to her a little.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Sha's set up her resolution already sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: True, true, and this will confirm it the more, there's a chapter of hell, 'tis good to read this cold weather, terrify her, terrify her; go, read to her the horrible punishments for itching wantonness, the pains allotted for adultery; tell her her thoughts, her very dreams are answerable, say so; rip up the life of a courtesan, and show how loath some 'tis.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The gentleman would persuade me in time to disgrace myself, and speak ill of mine own function.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: This is the course I take, I'll teach the married man
A new selected strain, I admit none
But this pure virgin to her company,
Puh, that's enough; I'll keep her to her stint,
I'll put her to her pension,
She gets but her allowance, that's bare-one,
Few women but have that beside their own,
Ha, ha, ha, nay I'll put her hard toot.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Fain would I meet the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Push, fain would you meet him, why, you do not take the course.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: How earnestly she labours her, like a good wholesome sister of the family, she will prevail I hope.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is that the means?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: What is the means? I would as gladly to enjoy his sight, embrace it as the —

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Shall I have hearing? listen?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She's round with her i'faith.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: When husbands in their rankest suspicions dwell,
Then 'tis our best art to dissemble well,
Put but these notes in use, that I'll direct you,
He'll curse himself that ere he did suspect you,
Perhaps she will solicit you, as in trial
To visit such and such, still given denial,
let no persuasions sway you, they are but fetches
Set to betray you, jealousies, slights and reaches,
Seem in his sight to endure the sight of no man,
Put by all kisses, till you kiss in common,
Neglect all entertain, if he bring in
Strangers, keep you your chamber, be not seen;
If he chance steal upon you, let him find,
Some book lie open 'gainst an unchaste mind,
And quoted scriptures, though for your own pleasure,
You read some stirring pamphlet, and convey it
Under your skirt, the fittest place to lay it,
This is the course my wench to enjoy thy wishes,
Here you perform best, when you most neglect,
The way to daunt, is to outvie suspect,
Manage these principles but with art and life,
Welcome all nations, thou'rt an honest wife.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: She puts it home i'faith, e'en to the quick
From her elaborate action I reach that,
I must requite this maid, faith I'm forgetful.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Here lady, convey my heart unto him in this jewel,
Against you see me next you shall perceive
I have profited, in the mean season tell him
I am a prisoner yet, a'th master's side,
My husband's jealousy, that masters him, as he doth master me,
And as a keeper that locks prisoners up,
Is himself prisoned under his own key,
Even so my husband in restraining me,
With the same ward bars his own liberty.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I'll tell him how you wish it, and I'll wear
My wits to the third pile, but all shall clear.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I owe you more than thanks, but that I hope
My husband will requite you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Think you so lady? he has small reason for't.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: What done so soon? away, to't again, to't again, good wench to't again, leave her not so, where left you. come.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Faith I am weary sir.
I cannot draw her from her strict opinion.
With all the arguments that sense can frame.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No; let me come, fie wife, you must consent; what opinion is't, let's hear?

sp.speaker: Curtiz
sp.p: Fondly and wilfully she retains that thought, that every sin is damned.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: O fie, fie, wife! Pea, pea, pea, pea, how have you lost your time? for shame be converted: there's a diabolical opinion indeed; than you may think that usury were damned: you're a fine merchant i'faith; or bribery? you know the law well; or sloth? would some of the clergy heard you i'faith; or pride? you come at court; or gluttony? you're not worthy to dine at an alderman's table:
sp.l: Your only deadly sin's adultery,
That villainous ringworm, woman's worst requital,
'Tis only lechery that's damned to'th pit-hole;
Ah, that's an arch-offence, believe it squall,
All sins are venial but venereal.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: I've said enough to her.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And she will be ruled by you.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Fah.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: I'll pawn my credit on't; come hither lady,
I will not altogether rest ingrateful,
Here, wear this ruby for thy pains and counsel.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: It is not so much worth sir, I am a very ill counsellor truly.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Go too I say.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: You're too blame i'faith sir, I shall ne'er deserve it.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Thou hast don't already: farewell sweet virgin, prithee let's see thee oftener.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Such gifts will soon entreat me.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Wife, as thou lovest the quiet of my breast,
Embrace her counsel, yield to her advices;
Thou wilt find comfort in 'em in the end;
Thou'lt feel an alteration, prithee think on't:
Mine eyes can scarce refrain.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Keep in your dew sir, lest when you would, you want it.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I've pawned my credit on't, ah didst thou know, the sweet fruit once, thou'dst never let it go.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis that I strive to get.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And still do so.

div.head: Incipit actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter sir bounteous with two knights.

sp.speaker: First,
sp.p: You have been too much like your name sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O not so, good knights, not so, you know my humour; most welcome good sir Andro Pelcut, sir Aquitaino Colewort, most welcome.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Thanks good sir bounteous.

div.stage: At the other, enter in haste a footman.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: O, cry your worship heartily mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now linen stockings, and threescore mile a day; whose footman art thou?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Pray can your worship tell me, hoh, hoh, hoh, if my l. be come in yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Thy l! what l?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: My l. Owemuch sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My l. Owemuch! I have heard much speech of that l. has great acquaintance i'th city; that l. has been much followed.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: And is still sir; he wants no company when he's in London: he's free of the mercers, and there's none of 'em all dare cross him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And they did, he'd turn over a new leaf with 'em; he would make 'em all weary on't i'th end: much fine rumor have I heard of that l. yet had I never the fortune to set eye upon him; art sure he will alight here footman? I am afraid thou'rt mistook.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Thinks your worship so sir? by your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Puh; passion of me, footman, why pumps I
say come back.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Does your worship call?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither I say, I am but afraid on't, would it might happen so well, how dost know? did he name the house with the great turret a'th top?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: No saith did he not sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither I say, did he speak of a cloth a gold chamber?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Not one word by my troth sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come again you lousy seven mile an hour?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: I beseech your worship detain me not.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Was there no talk of a fair pair of organs, a great guilt candlestick, and a pair of silver snuffers?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: 'Twere sin to belie my lord, I heard no such words sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A pox confine thee, come again, puh,

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Your worship will undo me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Was there no speech of a long dining room, a huge kitchen, large meat, and a broad dresser board?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: I have a greater maw to that indeed, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Whom did he name?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Why one sir bounteous progress.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah, a, a, I am that sir bounteous you progressive roundabout rascal.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Laughs, puh —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I knew I should have him i'th end, there's not a lord will miss me I thank their good honours, 'tis a fortune laid upon me, they can sent out their best entertainment, I have a kind of complemental gift given me above ordinary country knights, and how soon, 'tis smelled out I warrant ye, there's not one knight i'th shear able to entertain a lord i'th cue, or a lady i'th nick like me, like me, there's a kind of grace belongs to't, a kind of art which naturally slips from me, I know not on't I promise you, 'tis gone before I'm aware on't, cuds me I forget myself, where —

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Does your worship call?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Run sirrah, call in my chief gentleman i'th chain of gold, expedite; and how does my good lord? I never saw him before in my life, a cup of bastard for this footman.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: My lord has travailed this five year sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Travailed this five year? how many children has he? some bastard I say.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: No bastard an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A cup of sack to strengthen his wit, the footman's a fool; o, come hither master Gunwater, come hither, send presently to master pheasant for one of his hens, there's partridge i'th house.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: And wild-duck an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And woodcock an't please thy worship.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: And woodcock an't please your worship, I had thought to have spoke before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Remember the pheasant, down with some plover, clap down six woodcocks, my love's coming; now sir.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: An't please your worship there's a lord and his followers newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Dispatch I say, dispatch, why where's my music? he's come indeed.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit like a lord with his comrades in blue coats.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Footman.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Folli.
sp.p: Run swiftly with my commendations to s. Jasper Topas we'll ride and visit him i'th morning say.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Your lordship's charge shall be effected.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: That courtly comely form, should present to me sir bounteous progress.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: You've found me out my lord, I cannot hide myself, your honour in most spaciously welcome.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: In this forgive me sir, that being a stranger to your houses,
And you, I make my way so bold, and presume
Rather upon your kindness than your knowledge,
Only your bounteous disposition.
Fame hath divulged, and is to me well known.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay, and your lordship know my disposition, you know me better than they that know my person; your honour is so much the welcomer for that.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Thanks good sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, it has been often my ambition my l. both in respect of your honourable presence, and the prodigal fame that keeps even stroke with your unbounded worthiness;
sp.l: To have wished your lordship, where your lordship is
A noble guest in this unworthy seat:
Your lordship ne'er heard my organs.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Heard of 'em sir bounteous, but never heard 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: They're but double guilt my l. some hundred and fifty pound wilt fit your lordship with such another pair.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Indeed sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O my L. I have a present suit to you.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: To me sir bounteous, and you could ne'er speak at fitter time? for I'm here present to grant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Your lordship has been a traveller.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Some five year sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I have a grandchild my l. I love him; and when I die I'll do somewhat for him: I'll tell your honour the worst of him, a wild lad he has been.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: So we have been all sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So we have been all indeed my l. I thank your lordship's assistance; some comic pranks he has been guilty of; but I'll pawn my credit for him, an honest trusty bosom.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And that's worth all sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And that's worth all indeed my l. for he's like to have all when I die; imberbis iwenis, his chin has no more prickles yet then a midwife's: there's great hope of his wit his hair's so long a coming; shall I be bold with your honour, to prefer this aforesaid Ganymede to hold a plate under your lordship's cup?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You wrong both his worth, and your bounty, and you call that boldness; sir I have heard much good of that young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay has a good wit i'faith my L.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Has carried himself always generously.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Are you advised of that my l.? has carried many things cleanly: I'll show your lordship my will, I keep it above in an outlandish box; the whoreson boy must have all: I love him, yet he shall ne'er find it as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Well sir, for your sake, and his own deserving, I'll reserve a place for him nearest to my secrets.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I understand your good lordship, you'll make him your secretary: my music, give my l. a taste of his welcome.

div.stage: A strain played by the consort, sir bounteous makes a courtly honour to that l. and seems to foot the tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So, how like you our airs my lord? are they choice?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: They're seldom matched believe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The consort of mine own household.

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p: Ye sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The musicians are in ordinary, yet no ordinary musicians: your lordship shall hear my organs now.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: O I beseech you sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My organist.
sp.stage: The organs play, and covered dishes march over the stage.
sp.p: Come my l. how does your honour relish my organ?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A very proud air i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O, how can't choose, a Walloon plays upon 'em, and a Welshman blows wind in their breech.

div.stage: Enter sir bounteous with Folly-wit, and his consorts towards his lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
You must pardon us my l. hasty cates, your honour
has had e'en a hunting meal on't; and now I am like to bring your lordship to as mean a lodging, a hard down bed i'faith my l. poor cambric sheets, and a cloth a tissue canopy, the curtains indeed were wrought in Venice, with the story of the prodigal child in silk and gold, only the swine are left out my l. for spoiling the curtains.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: It was well prevented sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Silken rest, harmonious slumbers, and venereal dreams to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: The like to kind sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Fie, not to me my l. I'm old, passed dreaming of such vanities.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Old men should dream best.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Their dreams indeed my l. you've gi'nt us: tomorrow your lordship shall see my cocks, my fishponds, my park, my champion grounds; I keep champers in my house can show your lordship some pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Sir bounteous you e'en whelm me with delights.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Once again a musical night to your honour; I'll trouble your lordship no more.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Good rest sir bounteous; so, come, the vizards, where be the masking suits?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: In your lordship's portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Peace lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I had rather have war, captain.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Puh, the plot's ripe; come, to our business lad, though guilt condemns, 'tis gilt must make us glad.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nay, and you be at your distinctions captain, I'll follow behind no longer.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Get you before then, and whelm your nose with your vizard, go.
sp.l: Now grandsire, you that hold me at hard meat,
And keep me out at the dags end, I'll fit you;
Under his lordship's leave, all must be mine
He and his will confesses, what I take then
Is but a borrowing of so much before hand;
I'll pay him again when he dies, in so many blacks,
I'll have the church hung round with a noble a yard,
Or requite him in scutcheons, let him trap me
In gold, and I'll lap him in lead; quid pro quo: I
Must look none of his angels in the face forsooth,
Until his face be not worth looking on; tut lads,
Let sires and grandsires keep us low, we must
Live when they're flesh, as well as when they're dust.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Go, sirrah, run presently to m. penitent brothel; you know his lodging, knock him up, I know he cannot sleep for sighing; tell him I've happily bethought a mean,
sp.l: To make his purpose prosper in each limb,
Which only rests to be approved by him:
Make haste, I know he thirsts for't.
sp.p: Within. O.

div.stage: Enter in a masking suit with a vizard in his hand, Folly-wit.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Hark, they're at their business.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: Thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Gag that gaping rascal, though he be my grandsire's chief gentleman i'th chain of gold, I'll have no pity of him; how now lads?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: All's sure and safe, on with your vizard sir; the servants are all bound.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: There's one care passed then, come follow me lads, I'll lead you now to'th point, and top of all your fortunes; yo'n lodging is my grandsires.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: So, so, lead on, on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here's a captain worth the following, and a wit worth a man's love and admiring!

div.stage: Enter with sir bounteous in his nightgown.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O gentlemen, and you be kind gentlemen, what countrymen are you?

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p: Lincolnshire men sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I am glad of that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And why should you be glad of that?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O, the honestest thieves of all come out of Lincolnshire; the kindest natured gentlemen; they'll rob a man with conscience: they have a feeling of what they go about, and will steal with tears in their eyes: ah pitiful gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Push, money, money, we come for money.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Is that all you come for? Ah what a beast was I to put out my money tother day: alas good gentlemen, what shift shall I make for you? pray come again another time.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Tut, tut sir, money.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O not so loud sir, you're too shrill a gentleman; I have a l. lies in my house, I would not for the world his honour should be disquieted.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Who my l. Owemuch? we have taken order with him before hand, he lies bound in his bed and all his followers.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Who my l? bound my l? Alas what did you mean to bind my l? he could keep his bed well enough without binding: you've undone me in't already, you need rob me no farther.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Which is the key, come?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah I perceive now, you're no true Lincolnshire spirits; you come rather out of Bedfordshire, we cannot lie quiet in our beds for you: so, take enough my masters; spur a free horse, my name's sir bounteous, a merry world i'faith; what knight but I keep open house at midnight? well, there should be a conscience, if one could hit upon't.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Away now, cease upon him, bind him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Is this your court of equity? why should I be bound for mine own money? but come, come, bind me, I have need on't; I have been too liberal tonight , keep in my hands: nay, as hard as you list; I am too good to bear my l. company, you have watched your time my masters; I was knighted at Westminster, but many of these nights will make me a knight of Windsor; you've deserved so well my
masters; I bid you all to dinner tomorrow, I would I might have your companies i'faith, I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: O ho sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pray meddle not with my organs, to put 'em out of tune.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: O no, here's better music sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah pox feast you.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Dispatch with him, away; so, thank you good grandsire; this was bounteously done of him i'faith; it came somewhat hard from him at first; for indeed nothing comes stiff from an old man but money: and he may well stand upon that, when he has nothing else to stand upon: where's our Portmantua?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Here bully-captain.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: In with the purchase, 'twill lie safe enough there under's nose I warrant you: what, is all sure?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's sure captain.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You know what follows now, one villain binds his fellows; go, we must be all bound for our own securities rascals, there's no dallying upo'the point; you conceit me: there is a l. to be found bound in the morning, and all his followers, can you pick out that l. now?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O admirable spirit!

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You ne'er plot for your safeties, so your wants be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: But if we bind one another, how shall the last man be bound?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Pox on't, I'll have the footman scape.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: That's I, I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p:
The footman of all other will be supposed to scape, for he comes in no bed all night; but lies in's clothes, to be first ready i'th morning: the horse and he lies in litter together; that's the right fashion of your bonny footman: and his freedom will make the better for our purpose; for we must have one i'th morning to unbind the knight, that we may have our sport within ourselves: we now arrive at the most ticklish point, to rob, and take our ease, to be thieves and
lie by't, looker to't lads, it concerns every man's gullet; I'll not have the jest spoiled, that's certain, though it hazard a windpipe: I'll either go like a l. as I came, or be hanged like a thief as I am; and that's my resolution.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Troth a match captain, of all hands.

div.stage: Enter courtesan with m. penitent brothel.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: O m. penitent brothel!

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: What is't sweet lady Gulman, that so seizes on thee with rapture and admiration?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: A thought, a trick, to make you sir especially happy, and yet I myself a saver by it.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I would embrace that lady with such courage, I would not leave you on the losing hand.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I will give trust to you sir, the cause then why I raised you from your bed so soon; wherein I know sighs would not let you sleep, thus understand it: you love that woman (M. Harebrains wife) which no invented means can crown with freedom, for your desires and her own wish, but this, which in my slumbers did present itself.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I'm covetous lady.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: You know her husband lingering in suspect, locks her from all society, but mine.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Most true.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: I only am admitted, yet hitherto that has done you no real happiness; by my admittance I cannot perform that deed, that should please you, you know: wherefore thus I've conveyed it, I'll counterfeit a fit of violent sickness.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Nay 'tis not so good by my faith, but to do you good.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: And in that sense I called it, but take me with you lady; would it be probable enough to have a sickness so suddenly violent?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p:
Puh, all the world knows women are soon down;
we can be sick when we have a mind to't, catch an ague with the wind of our fans, surfeit upon the rump of a lark, and bestow ten pound in physic upon't; we're likest ourselves when we're down: 'tis the easiest art and cunning for our sect to counterfeit sick, that are always full of sits when we are well; for since we were made for a weak imperfect creature, we can sit that best that we are made for: I thus translated, and yourself slipped into the form of a physician.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I a physician lady, talk not on't I beseech you, I shall shame the whole college.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Tutman, any guacksaluing terms will serve for this purpose; for I am pitifully haunted with a brace of elder brothers, new perfumed in the first of their fortunes, and I shall see how forward their purses will be to the pleasing of my palate, and restoring of my health; lay on load enough upon 'em, and spare 'em not, for they're good plump fleshly asses, and may well enough bear it: let gold, amber, and dissolved pearl, be common ingrediences, and that you cannot compose a cullis without 'em: put but this cunningly in practice, it shall be both a sufficient recompense for all my pains in your love, and the ready means to make mistress Harebrain; way, by the visiting of me to your mutual desired company.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I applaud thee, kiss thee, and will constantly embrace it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ho, Gunwater!

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Singlestone!

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Jenkin, uva, ha, ho.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Ewen!

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Simcod!

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Footman! whewe —

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: O good your worship, let me help your good old worship.

div.stage: Enter sir Bount, with a cord half unbound, foot with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah poor honest footman, how didst thou scape this massacre?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: E'en by miracle, and lying in my clothes sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I think so, I would I had lain in my clothes to footman, so I had scaped 'em; I could have but risse like a beggar then, and so I do now, till more money come in; but nothing afflicts me so much, my poor geometrical footman, as that the barbarous villains should lay violence upon my l. Ah, the binding of my l. cuts my heart in two pieces; so, so, 'tis well, I thank thee, run to thy fellows, undo 'em, undo 'em, undo 'em.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Alas, if my l. should miscarry, they're unbound already sir; they have no occupation but sleep, feed, and fart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: If I be not ashamed to look my l i'th face, I'm a sarassen my l.

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: One may see he has been scared, a pox on 'em for their labours.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Singlestone!

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Singlestone? I'll ne'er answer to that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Suchman -

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Suchman? nor that neither i'faith; I am not brought so low, though I be old.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Who's that i'th chamber?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good morrow my l. 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Sir bounteous good morrow, I would give you my hand sir, but I cannot come at it; is this the courtesy a'th country sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Your lordship grieves me more than all my loss; 'tis the unnatural'st sight that can be found, to see a noble gentleman hard-bound.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Trust me, I thought you had been better beloved sir bounteous; but I see you have enemies sir, and your friends fare the worse for 'em: I like your talk better than your lodging; I ne'er lay harder in a bed of down; I have had a mad night's rest on't: can you not guess what they should be sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Faith Lincolnshire men my lord.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How? fie, fie, believe it not sir, these lie not far off I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Think you so my lord?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: I'll be burned and they do, some that use to your house sir, and are familiar with all the conveyances.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: This is the commodity of keeping open house my lord, that makes so many shut their doors about dinner time.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: They were resolute villains, I made myself known to 'em, told 'em what I was; gave 'em my honourable word not to disclose 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O saucy unmannerly villains!

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And think you the slaves would trust me upon my word?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: They would not?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Forsooth no, I must pardon 'em, they told me lords promises were mortal, and commonly die within half an hour after they are spoken; they were but gristles, and not one amongst a hundred come to any full growth, or perfection, and therefore though I were a l. I must enter into bond.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Insupportable rascals.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Troth I'm of that mind sir bounteous you fared the worse for my coming hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah good my lord, but I'm sure your lordship fared the worse.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Pray pity not me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Is not your honour sore about the brawn of the arm? A murrain meet 'em, I feel it.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: About this place sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: You feel as it were a twinge my lord?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Ay, e'en a twinge, you say right.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A pox discover 'em, that twinge I feel too.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: But that which disturbs me most sir bounteous lies here.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: True, about the wrist, a kind of tumid numbness.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You say true sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bount.
sp.p: The reason of that my lord is, the pulses had no play.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Mass so I gest it.

sp.speaker: Sir boun
sp.p: A mischief swell 'em, for I feel that to.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: 'Slid here's a house haunted indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A word with you sir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How now Singlestone?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I'm sorry my lord your lordship has lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pup, pup, pup, pup, pup.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: What have I lost? speak?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A good night's sleep say.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Speak, what have I lost I say?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A good nights sleep my lord, nothing else. Curtains drawn

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: That's true, my cloth's come.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: My lords clothes, his honour's rising.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hist, well said, come hither, what has my lord lost, tell me, speak softly?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: His lordship must know that sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hush, prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: 'Twill do you no pleasure to know't sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yet again? I desire it I say.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Since your worship will needs know't, they have stolen away a jewel in a blue silk ribbon of a hundred pound price, beside some hundred pounds in fair spur-royals.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: That's some two hundred it'h total.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Your worship's much about it sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come follow me, I'll make that whole again in so much money, let not my lord know on't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O pardon me sir bounteous, that were a dishonour to my lord, should it come to his ear, I should hazard my undoing by it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How should it come to his ear? if you be my lords chief man about him, I hope you do not use to speak, unless you be paid for't, and I had rather give you a councillor's double fee to hold your peace, come, go too, follow me I say.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: There will be scarce time to tell it sir, my lord will away instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: His honour shall stay dinner by his leave , I'll prevail with him so far; and now I remember a jest; I bade the whoreson thieves to dinner last night, I would I might have their companies, a pox poison 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith and you are like to have no other guess sir bounteous, if you have none but us, I'll give you that gift i'faith.

div.head: Incipit actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter master Harebrain with two elder brothers, master inesse, and master possibility.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: You see bold guests master Hareb.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: You're kindly welcome to my house; good master inesse, and master possibility.

sp.speaker: Inesse
sp.p: That's our presumption sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Rafe?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Call down your mistress to welcome these two gentlemen my friends.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I will observe her carriage, and watch the slippery revolutions of her eye, I'll lie in wait for every glance she gives, and poise her words it'h balance of suspect, if she but swag she's gone, either on this hand over familiar, or this, too neglectful, it does behove her carry herself even.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: But master Hareb.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: True, I hear you sir; was't you said?

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: I have not spoke it yet sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Right, so I say.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p:
Is it not strange, that in so short a time, my little
lady Gulman should be so violently handled?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: O, sickness has no mercy sir,
It neither pities lady's lip, nor eye,
It crops the rose out of the virgin's cheek,
And so deflowers her that was ne'er deflowered,
Fools then are maids to lock from men that treasure,
Which death will pluck, and never yield 'em pleasure;
Ah gentlemen, though I shadow it, that sweet virgin's sickness grieves me not lightly, she was my wife's only delight and company;
Did you not hear her gentlemen, it'h midst
Of her extremest fit, still how she called upon my wife,
Remembered still my wife, sweet mistress Harebrain,
When she sent for me, a one side of her bed stood the physician,
The scrivener on the other, two horrible objects, but,
Mere opposites in the course of their lives, for the scrivener
Binds folks, and the physician makes them loose.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: But not loose of their bonds sir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No by my faith sir, I say not so, if the physician could make 'em lose of their bonds, there's many a one would take physic, that dares not now for poisoning, but as I was telling of you, her will was fashioning, wherein I found her best and richest jewel, given as a legacy unto my wife, when I read that, I could not refrain weeping, well of all other, my wife has most reason to visit her, if she have any good nature in her, she'll show it there, now sir where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: She desires you, and the gentlemen your friends, to hold her excused, sha's a fit of an ague now upon her, which begins to shake her

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Where does it shake her most?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: All over her body sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Shake all her body? 'tis a saucy fit, I'm jealous of that ague, pray walk in gentlemen, I'll see you instantly.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Now they are absent sir, 'tis no such thing.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.l: My mistress has her health sir,
But 'tis her suit, she may confine herself
From sight of all men, but your own dear self sir,
For since the sickness of that modest virgin
Her only company, she delights in none;

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No; visit her again, commend me to her, tell her they're gone, and only I myself walk here to exchange a word or two with her.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: I'll tell her so sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Fool that I am, and madman, beast! what worse?
Suspicious o'er a creature that deserves
The best opinion, and the purest thought,
Watchful o'er her that is her watch herself,
To doubt her ways, that looks too narrowly
Into her own defects; ay, foolish-fearful
Have often rudely, out of giddy flames
Barred her those objects which she shuns herself,
Thrice I've had proof of her most constant temper,
Come I at unawares by stealth upon her,
I find her circled in with divine writs
Of heavenly meditations; here and there
Chapters with leaves tucked up, which when I see
They either tax pride or adultery,
Ah let me curse myself, that could be jealous
Of her whose mind no sin can make rebellious.
And here the unmatched comes, now wife i'faith they're gone,
Push, see how fearful 'tis, will you not credit me?
sp.p: They're gone i'faith, why, think you I'll betray you? come, come, thy delight and mine, thy only virtuous friend, thy sweet instructress is violently taken, grievous sick, and which is worse, she mends not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Her friends are sorry for that sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She calls still upon thee, poor soul, remembers thee still, thy name whirls in her breath, where's mistress Harebrain says she?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Alas good soul,

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p:
She made me weep thrice, sh'as put thee in a jewel
in her will.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: E'en to th' last gasp a kind soul.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Take my man, go, visit her.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Pray pardon me sir, alas my visitation cannot help her.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: O yet the kindness of a thing wife; still she holds the same rare temper; take my man I say.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would not take your man sir, though I did purpose going.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No? thy reason?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: The world's condition is itself so vild sir,
'Tis apt to judge the worst, of those deserve not,
'Tis an ill-thinking age, and does apply
All to the form of it own luxury,
This censure flies from one, that, from another,
That man's her squire, says he; her pimp, the tother,
She's of the stamp, a third, fourth, I ha' known her:
I've heard this, not without a burning cheek:
Then our attires are taxed, our very gate
Is called in question, where a husband's presence
Scatters such thoughts, or makes 'em sink for fear
Into the hearts that breed 'em, nay surely if I went sir,
I would entreat your company.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Mine? prithee wife, I have been there already.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: That's all one; although you bring me but to'th door sir, I would entreat no farther.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Thou'rt such a wife; why I will bring thee thither then, but not go up I swear.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I'faith you shall not, I do not desire it sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why then content.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Give me your hand you will do so sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why there's my lip I will.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why then I go sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: With me or no man, incomparable such a woman. Exeunt.

div.stage: Viols, gallipots, plate, and an hourglass by her. The courtesan on a bed, for her counterfeit fut. To her, master penitent brothel, like a doctor of physic.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: Lady?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Ha, what news?

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: There's one sir bounteous progress newly alighted from his foot-cloth, and his mare waits at door, as the fashion is.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: 'Slid, 'tis the knight that privately maintains me, a little short-old. spiny gentleman, in a great doublet.

sp.speaker: M. peni
sp.p: The same, I know 'em.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He's my sole revenue, meat, drink, and raiment; my good physician work upon him, I'm weak.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why, where be these ladies? these plump soft delicate creatures? ha?

sp.speaker: M. pevi.
sp.p: Who would you visit sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Visit, who? what are you with the plague in your mouth?

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: A physician sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Then you are a loose-liver sir, I have put you to your purgation.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: But you need none, you're purged in a worse fashion,

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Ah, sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Sweet sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Passion of me, what an alteration's here? Rosamond sick old Harry? here's a sight able to make an old man shrink, I was lusty when I came in, but I am down now i'faith, mortality, yea? this puts me in mind of a hole seven foot deep, my grave, my grave, my grave, hist, master doctor a word sir, hark, 'tis not the plague? is't?

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: The plague sir, no?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: He never asks whether it be the pox or no, and of the twain that had been more likely.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now my wench? how dost?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Huh, weak Knigh, huh.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: She says true, he's a weak knight indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Where does it hold thee most, wench?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: All parts alike sir.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: She says true still, for it holds her in none.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hark in thine ear, thou'rt breeding of young bones, I am afraid I have got thee with child i'faith.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I fear that much sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O, o, if it should, a young progress when all's done.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You have done your good will sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I see by her, 'tis nothing but a surfeit of Venus i'faith, and though I be old, I have gin't her, but since I had the power to make thee sick, I'll have the purse to make thee whole, that's certain; master doctor.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Let's hear I pray, what is't you minister to her?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Marry sir, some precious cordial, some costly refocillation, a composure comfortable and restorative.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that, that, that.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: No poorer ingrediences than the liquor of coral, clear amber, or succinum, unicorn's horn six grains, magisterium, perlarum one scruple.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Ossis de cord cervi half a scruple, aurum potabile or his tincture.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Very precious sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: All which being finely contunded, and mixed in a stone or glass mortar, with the spirit of diamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay pray be patient sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: That's impossible, I cannot be patient and a physician too sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O, cry you mercy, that's true sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: All which aforesaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ay, there you left sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: When it is almost exsiccate or dry, I add thereto olei succini, olei masi, et sinamoni.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So sir, olei masi, that same oil of maze is a great comfort to both the counters.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: And has been of a long time sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Well, be of good cheer wench, there's gold for
thee; huh, let her want for nothing m. doctor, a poor kinswoman of mine, nature binds me to have a care of her; there I gulled you m. doctor: gather up a good spirit wench, the fit will away, 'tis but a surfeit of gristles: ha, ha, I have fitted her; an old knight and a cock a'th game still, I have not spurs for nothing I see.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: No by my faith, they're hatched, they cost you an angel sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Look to her good m. doctor, let her want nothing, I've given her enough already, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: So, is he gone?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: He's like himself gone.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Here's somewhat to set up with; how soon he took occasion to slip into his own flattery, soothing his own defects; he only fears he has done that deed, which I ne'er feared to come from him in my life, this purchase came unlooked for.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: H'ist, the pair of sons and heirs.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: O, they're welcome, they bring money.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: M. doctor.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I come to you gentleman.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: How does she now?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Faith much after one fashion sir.

sp.speaker: Iness
sp.p: There's hope of life sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: I see no signs of death of her.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: That's some comfort; will she take any thing yet?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, she'll take still: sh'as a kind of facility in taking: how comes your band bloody sir?

sp.speaker: Iness
sp.p: You may see I met with a scab sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Diversa genera scabierum, as Pliny reports, there are divers kind of scabs.

sp.speaker: Iness
sp.p: Pray let's hear 'em sir.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p:
An itching scab, that is your harlot; a sore scab, your usurer; a running, your promoter; a broad scab, your intelligencer; but a white scab, that's a scald knave and a
pander: but to speak truth, the only scabs we are now a day's troubled withal, are new officers.

sp.speaker: Inesse.
sp.p: Why now you come to mine sir, for I'll be sworn one of them was very busy about my head this morning, and he should be a scab by that, for they are ambitious and covet the head.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Why you saw I derived him sir?

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: You physicians are mad gentlemen.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: We physicians see the most sights of any men living, you're astronomers look upward into'th air, we look downward into'th body, and indeed we have power upward and downward.

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: That you have i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: Lady, how cheer you now?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: The same woman still, huh.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: That's not good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Little alteration, fie, fie, you have been to lavish gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: Puh, talk not of that lady, thy health's worth a million; here m. doctor, spare for no cost.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: Look what you find there sir.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: What do you mean gentlemen, put up, put up, you see I'm down and cannot strive with you, I would rule you else; you have me at advantage, but if ever I live, I will requite it deeply.

sp.speaker: Iness
sp.p: Tut an't come to that once, we'll requite ourselves well enough.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: Mist. Harebrain, lady, is setting forth to visit you too.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Ha, huh.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: There struck the minute that brings forth the birth of all my joys and wishes; but see the jar now, how shall I rid these from her?

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.p: Pray gentleman, stay not above an hour from my sight.

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: 'Sfoot we are not going lady.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Subtly brought about, yet 'twill not do, they'll stick by't; a word with you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: What says m. doctor?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: She wants but settling of her sense with rest, one hours sleep gentlemen would set all parts in tune.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: He says true i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: Get her to sleep m. doctor, we'll both sit here and watch by her.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Hell's angels watch you, no art can prevail with 'em; what with the thought of joys, and sight of crosses, my wits are at Hercules' pillars, non plus ultra.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: M. doctor, m. doctor?

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Here lady.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Your physic works, lend me your hand.

sp.speaker: Possibility
sp.p: Farewell sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ines.
sp.p: Adieu m. doctor.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.l: Let me admire thee,
The wit of man, wanes and decreases soon,
But women's wit is ever at full moon.
There shot a star from heaven,
I dare not yet behold my happiness.
The splendour is so glorious and so piercing.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Mistress Harebrain, give my wit thanks hereafter, your wishes are in sight, your opportunity spacious.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you but hear a word from me?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Whooh —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My husband himself brought me to'th door, walks below for my return; jealousy is prick-eared, and will hear the waging of a hair.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Pish, you're a faint-liver, trust yourself with your pleasure, and me with your security, go.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: The fullness of my wish.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Of my desire.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: Beyond this sphere I never will aspire.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: I'll listen, now the flesh draws nigh her end,
at such a time women exchange their secrets,
And ransack the close corners of their hearts;
What many years hath whelmed, this hour imparts.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Pray sit down, there's a low stool, good mistress Harebrain, this was kindly done; huh give me your hand; huh, alas how cold you are: e'en so is your husband, that worthy wise gentleman; as comfortable a man to woman in my case, as ever trod — huh — shoe leather, love him, honour him, stick by him, he lets you want nothing, that's fit for a woman; and to be sure on't, he will see himself that you want it not.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And so I do i'faith, 'tis right my humour.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You live a lady's life with him, go where you will, ride when you will, and do what you will.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Not so, not so neither, she's better looked to.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I know you do, you need not tell me that; 'twere e'en pity of your life i'faith, if ever you should wrong such an innocent gentleman; fie mistress Harebrain, what do you mean? come you to discomfort me? nothing but weeping with you?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She's weeping, t'as made her weep, my wife shows her good nature already.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Still, still weeping? huff, huff, huff, why how now woman? heigh, high, high, for shame leave; suh, suh, she cannot answer me for snobbing.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: All this does her good, beshrew my heart and I pity her, let her shed tears till morning; I'll stay for her, she shall have enough on't by my good will; I'll not be her hindrance.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: O no, lay your hand here mistress Harebrain: I there, o there, there lies my pain good gentlewoman: sore? O ay, I can scarce endure your hand upon't.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Poor soul, how she's tormented.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I eat a cullis an hour since.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: There's some comfort in that yet, she may scape it.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: O it lies about my heart much.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I'm sorry for that i'faith, she'll hardly scape it.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Bound, no, no, I'd a very comfortable stool this morning.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I'm glad of that i'faith, that's a good sign, I smell, she'll scape it now.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Will you be going then?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Fall back, she's coming.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Thanks good mistress Harebrain, welcome sweet mistress Harebrain, pray commend me to the good gentleman your husband.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I could do that myself now.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: And to my uncle Winchcomb, and to my aunt Lipsalve, and to my cousin Falsetop, and to my cousin Lickit, and to my cousin horseman, and to all my good cousins in Clerkenwell , and saint Joneses'.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: At three days' end my husband takes a journey.

sp.speaker: M. penitent
sp.p: O thence I derive a second meeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: May it prosper still, till then I rest a captive to his will: once again health, rest, and strength to thee sweet lady: farewell, you witty squall; good m. doctor have a care to her body if yous stand her friend, I know you can do her good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Take pity of your waiter, go: farewell sweet mistress Harebrain.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Welcome sweet wife, alight upon my lip, never was hour spent better.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, were you within the hearing sir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: I that I was i'faith, to my great comfort; I deceived you there wife, ha, ha;
I do entreat thee, nay conjure thee wife
Upon my love, or what can more be said?
Oftener to visit this sick virtuous maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Be not so fierce, your will shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why then I see thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.l: Art of ladies.
When plots are e'en past hope, and hang their head,
Set with a woman's hand, they thrive and spread.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit with lieutenant maw-worme, ancient hoboy, and the rest of his consorts.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Wast not well managed, you necessary mischiefs? did the plot want either life or art?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: 'Twas so well captain, I would you could make such another muss at all adventures.

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p: Dost cal't a muss? I am sure my grandsire ne'er got his money worse in his life, than I got it from him, if ever he did cozen the simple; why I was born to revenge their quarrel; if ever oppress the widow? Ay, a fatherless child have done as much for him; and so 'tis through the world either in jest or earnest, let the usurer look for't, for craft recoils in the end, like an overcharged musket, and maims the very hand that puts fire to't; there needs no more but a usurer's own blow to strike him from hence to hell, 'twill set him forward with a vengeance; but here lay the jest whoresons, my grandsire thinking in his conscience that we had not robbed him enough o'er night, must needs pity me it'h morning, and give me the rest.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Two hundred pounds in fair rose-nobles I protest.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Push, I knew he could not sleep quietly till he had paid me for robing of him too, 'tis his humour, and the humour of most of your rich men in the course of their lives; for you know, they always feast those mouths that are least needy, and give them more, that have too much already; and what call you that, but robing of themselves a courtlier way; o.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Cuds me, how now captain?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A cold fit that comes over my memory, and has a shrewd pull at my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: What's that sir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Is it for certain, lieutenant, that my grandsire keeps an uncertain creature, a quean?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I that's too true sir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.l: So much the more preposterous for me, I shall
Hop shorter by that trick; she carries away the thirds at least;
'Twill prove entailed land I am afraid when all's done, i'faith
Nay, I have known a vicious-old-thought-acting father,
Damned only in his dreams, thirsting for game,
(When his best parts hung down their heads for shame,)
For his blanched harlot dispossess his son,
And make the pox his heir, 'twas gravely done:
How hadst thou first knowledge on't lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith from discourse, yet all the policy that I could use, I could not get her name.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Dull slave that never couldst spy it.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: But the manner of her coming was described to me.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How is the manner prithee?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Marry sir she comes, most commonly coached.

sp.speaker: Folly wit
sp.p: Most commonly coached indeed, for coaches are as common now adays, as some that ride in 'em, she comes most commonly coached.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: True, there I left sir, guarded with some leash of pimps.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Beside the coachman?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Right sir, then alighting, she's privately received by master Gunwater.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: That's my grandsire's chief gentleman it'h chain of gold, that he should live to be a pander, and yet look upon his chain and his velvet jacket

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then is your grandsire rounded it'h ear, the key given after the Italian fashion, backward, she closely conveyed into his closet, there remaining, till either opportunity smile upon his credit, or he send down some hot caudle to take order in his performance.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Peace, 'tis mine own i'faith, I ha't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: How now sir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Thanks, thanks to any spirit, that mingled it amongst my inventions.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Why master Folly-wit?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Captain?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.l: Give me scope and hear me,
I have begotten that means which will both furnish me,
And make that quean walk under his conceit.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: That were double happiness, to put thyself into money and her out of favour.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And all at one dealing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Sfoot I long to see that hand played,

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And thou shalt see't quickly i'faith; nay 'tis in grain, I warrant it hold colour: lieutenant, step behind yon hanging; if I mistook not at my entrance, there hangs the lower part of a gentlewoman's gown, with a mask and a chin-clout; bring all this way: nay, but do't cunningly now, 'tis a friend's house, and I'd use it so, there's a taste for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But prithee what wilt thou do with a gentlewoman's lower part?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Why use it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You've answered me indeed in that, I can demand no farther.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Well said lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: What will you do now sir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Come, come, thou shalt see a woman quickly made up here.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: But that's against kind captain, for they are always long a making ready.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And is not most they do against kind I prithee? to lie with their horsekeeper, is not that against kind? to wear half moons made of another's hair, is not that against kind? to drink down a man, she that should set him up, pray is not that monstrously against kind now? nay over with it lieutenant, over with it, ever while you live put a woman's clothes over her head: Cupid plays best at blindman buff.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: You shall have your will maintenance, I love mad tricks as well as you for your heart sir; but what shift will you make for upper body's captain?

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: I see now thou'rt an ass, why I'm ready.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Ready?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Why the doublet serves as well as the best, and is
most in fashion, were all male to th' middle, mankind from the beaver to'th bum, 'tis an Amazonian time, you shall have women shortly tread their husbands; I should have a couple of locks behind, prithee lieutenant find 'em out for me, and wind 'em about my hatband, nay you shall see, we'll be in fashion to a hair, and become all with probability, the most musty-visage critic shall not except against me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nay I'll give thee thy due behind thy back, thou art as mad a piece of clay —

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Clay! dost call thy captain clay? indeed clay was made to stop holes, he says true; did not I tell you rascals you should see a woman quickly made up?

sp.speaker: Antient.
sp.p: I'll swear for't captain.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Come, come, my mask and my chin-clout — come into'th court.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nay they were both ith' court long ago sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Let me see, where shall I choose two or three for pimps now? but I cannot choose amiss amongst you all, that's the best; well, as I am a quean, you were best have a care of me, and guard me sure, I give you warning before hand, 'tis a monkey taylde-age. Life, you shall go nigh to have half a dozen blithe fellows surprise me cowardly, carry me away with a pair of oars, and put in at Putney.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: We should laugh at that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Or shoot in upo'the coast of cue.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Two notable fit landing places for lechers, P. and C. Putney and Cue.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Well, say you have fair warning on't, the hair about the hat is as good as a flag upo'the pole at a common playhouse to waste company, and a chin-clout is of that powerful attraction I can tell you, 'twill draw more linen to't?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Fear not us captain, there's none here but can fight for a whore as well as some inns a courtman?

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Why then set forward; and as you scorn two shilling brothel, twelve penny pandarism, and such base bribes, guard me from bonny scribs, and bony scribes.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Hang 'em, pensions, and alowancces, four pence half penny a meal, hang 'em.

div.head: Incipit actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter in his chamber out of his study, master panitent, once, ill, a book in his hand reading.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.l: Ha? read that place again, — adultery
Draws the divorce twixt heaven and the soul!
Accursed man that standst divorced from heaven,
Thou wretched unthrift, that hast played away
Thy eternal portion at a minute's game,
To please the flesh, hast blotted out thy name:
Where were thy nobler meditations busied?
That they durst trust this body with itself,
This natural drunkard that undoes us all,
And makes our shame apparent in our fall.
Then let my blood pay fort, and vex and boil,
My soul I know would never grieve to th' death,
The eternal spirit that feeds her with his breath:
Nay I that knew the price of life and sin,
What crown is kept for continence, what for lust?
The end of man, and glory of that end
As endless as the giver:
To dote on weakness, slime, corruption, woman?
What is she, took asunder from her clothes?
Being ready, she consists of hundred pieces,
Much like your German cloak, and near allied
Both are so nice, they cannot go for pride.
Beside a greater fault, but too well known,
They'll strike to ten, when they should stop at one;
Within these three days the next meeting's fixed,
If I meet then, hell and my soul be mixed.
My lodging I know constantly, she not knows,
Sins hate is the best gift that sin bestows:
I'll ne'er embrace her more, — never — better witness, never.

div.stage: Enter the devil in her shape, claps him on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: What at a stand? the fitter for my company?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Celestial soldiers guard me, -

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: How now man? Alas did the quickness of my presence fright thee?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Shield me you ministers of faith and grace.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: Leave, leave, are you not ashamed to use such words to a woman?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Thou'rt a devil.

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.p: A devil? feel, feel man, has a devil flesh and bone?

sp.speaker: Mast paenitent
sp.p: I do conjure thee by that dreadful power —

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.l: The man has a delight to make me tremble;
Are these the fruits of thy adventurous love?
Was I enticed for this? to be soon rejected?
Come, what has changed thee so, delight;

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: Remember.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Leave my sight.

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.l: Have I this meeting wrought with cunning.
Which when I come I find thee shunning?
Rouse thy amorous thoughts and twine me,
All my interest I resign thee:
Shall we let slip this mutual hour,
Comes so seldom in her power?
Where's thy lip, thy clip, thy fathom?
Had women such loves. would't not mad 'em?
Art a man? or dost abuse one?
A love! and knowest not how to use one?
Come, I'll teach thee —

sp.speaker: Mast. pa.
sp.p: Do not follow.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.l: Once so firm and now so hollow?
When was place and season sweeter?
Thy bliss in sight and dar'st not meet her?
Where's thy courage youth and vigour?
Love's best pleased, when 'tis seared with rigour:
sear me then with veins most cheerful,
Women love no flesh that's fearful;
'Tis but a fit, come drink't away,
And dance and sing, and kiss and play — fa le
La, le la, fa le la, le la la; fa le la, fa la le
La le la.

sp.speaker: Mast. Paen.
sp.p: Torment me not.

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.p: Fa le la, fa le la, fa la la, loh.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Fury.

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.p: Fa le la, fa le la, fa la la loh.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
