sp.l: Devil! I do conjure thee once again,
By that soul-quaking thunder to depart,
And leave this chamber, freed from thy damned art.

sp.speaker: Succubus
sp.p: Stamps —

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: It has prevailed — o my sin-shaking sinews! what should I think? Jesper, why Jesper.

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: Sir! how now? what has disturbed you sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: A fit, a qualm, — is mistress Hargrave gone?

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: Who sir? mistress Hargrave?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Is she gone I say?

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: Gone? why she was never here yet.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: Why no sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Art sure on't.

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: Sure on't? if I be sure I breathe, and am myself?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: I like it not; — where kepst thou?

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: It'h next room sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Why she struck by thee man.

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: You'd make one mad sir, that a gentlewoman should steal by me and I not hear her, sfoot, one may hear the rusling of their bums almost an hour before we see 'em.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.l: I will be satisfied, — although to hazard,
What though her husband meet me? I am honest;
When men's intents are wicked, their guilt haunts 'em,
But when they're just, they're armed, and nothing daunts 'em.

sp.speaker: Jesper.
sp.p: What strange humour call you this? he dreams of women and both his eyes broad open!

div.stage: Enter at one door sir bounteous, at another gum-water.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why how now master Gumwater? what's the news with your haste?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: I have a thing to tell your worship —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why prithee tell me, speak man.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Your worship shall pardon me, I have better bringing up then so.

sp.speaker: Sir. Boun.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: 'Tis a thing made fit for your ear sir —

sp.speaker: Sir. Boun.
sp.p: O — oh — oh — cry you mercy, now I begin to taste you, — is she come?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: She's come sir?

sp.speaker: Sir boun
sp.p: Recovered, well and sound again?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: That's to be feared sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: She wears a linen cloth about her jaw,

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha, ha, haw, — why that's the fashion you whoreson Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: The fashion sir? live I so long time to see that a fashion, which rather was an emblem of dispraise, it was suspected much in monsieurs days.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in those days, that was a queasy time, our age is better hardened now, and put oftener in the fire, we are tried what we are: tut, the pox is as natural now, as an ague in the spring time, we seldom take physic without it; here, take this key, you knew what duties belong to't, go, — give order for a cullis, let there be a good fire made it'h matted chamber, do you hear sir? —

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: I know my office sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: An old man's venery is very chargeable my masters, there much cookery belongs to't.

div.stage: Enter Gumwater with Follywet in courtesans disguise, and masked.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Come lady, you know where you are now?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Yes, good master Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: This is the old closet you know.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I remember it well sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: There stands a casket, I would my yearly revenue were but worth the wealth that's locked in't lady; yet I have fifty pound a year wench.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Beside your apparel sir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Yes faith have I.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: But then you reckon your chain sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: No by my troth do I not, neither: faith and you consider me rightly sweet lady, you might admit a choice gentleman into your service.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: O, pray away sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Pusha come, come, you do but hinder your fortunes i'faith, I have the command of all the house, I can tell you, nothing comes into th' kitchen, but comes through my hands.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Pray do not handle me sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Faith you're too nice lady: and as for my secrecy you know I have vowed it often to you.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Vowed it? no, no, you men are fickle, —

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Fickle? — sfoot bind me lady —

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why I bind you by virtue of this chain to meet me tomorrow at the flower-de-luce yonder, between nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: And if I do not lady let me lose it, thy love and my best fortunes?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why now I'll try you, go too.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Farewell sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Welcome sweet coxcomb; by my faith a good induction, I perceive by his overworn phrase, and his action towards the middle region still there has been some saucy nibbling motion, and no doubt the cunning quean waited but for her prey, and I think 'tis better bestowed upon me for his soul's health; — and his bodies too; I'll teach the slave to be so bold yet, as once to offer to vault into his master's saddle i'faith: now casket, by your leave, I have seen your outside oft, but
that's no proof. Some have fair outsides that are nothing worth: ha? — now by my faith a gentlewoman of very good parts, diamond, ruby, saphire, onyx cum prolo silexque; if I do not wonder how the quean 'scaped tempting, I'm an hermaphrodite, sure she could lack nothing, but the devil to point to't, and I wonder that he should be missing; well, 'tis better as it is, this is the fruit of old-grunting-venery. Grandsire, you may thank your drab for this; o fie, in your crinkling days grandsire, keep a courtesan to hinder your grandchild, 'tis against nature i'faith, and I hope you'll be weary on't: now to my villains that lurk close below: who keeps a harlot tell him this from me, he needs nor thief, disease, nor enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah sirrah, methink I feel myself well toasted, bombasted, rubbed and refreshed; but i'faith I cannot forget to think how soon sickness has altered her — to my taste, I gave her a kiss at bottom o'th stairs, and byth' mass methought her breath had much ado to be sweet, like a thing compounded methought of wine, beer, and tobacco, I smelled much pudding in't. It may be but my fancy, or her physic: for this I know, her health gave such content, the fault rests in her sickness, or my scent. How dost thou now sweet girl, what well recovered? Sickness quite gone, ha? speak — ha? wench? Frank Gulman, why body of me, what's here? my casket wide open, broke open, my jewels stolen — why Gumwater —

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Anon anon sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: That were small manners sir i'faith, I'll find a time anon your worship's busy yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why Gumwater?

sp.speaker: Gum
sp.p: Foe nay then you'll make me blush i'faith sir. —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Where's this creature?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: What creature is't you'd have sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The worst that ever breathes.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: That's a wild boar sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: That's a vild whore sir; — where didst thou leave her rascal?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Who? your recreation sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My execration sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Where I was wont, in your worship's closet.

sp.speaker: Sir boun
sp.p: A pox engross her, it appears too true, see you this casket sir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: My chain, my chain, my chain, my one and only chain.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Thou runnest to much purpose now, Gumwater, ye? Is not a quean enough to answer for, but she must join a thief to't, a thieving quean, nay I have done with her i'faith, 'tis a sign sh'as been sick a late, for she's a great deal worse than she was, by my troth I would have pawned my life upon't, did she want anything? was she not supply de?
sp.l: Nay and liberally, for that's an old man's sin,
We'll feast our lechery, though we starve our kin.
Is not my name sir bounteous, am I not expressed there?
Ah fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, but I perceive
Though she have never so complete a friend,
A strumpet's love will have a waste i'th end,
And distaste the vessel: I can hardly bear this;
But say I should complain, perhaps she has pawned 'em,
Sfoot the judges will but laugh at it, and bid her borrow
More money of 'em, make the old fellow pay for's lechery,
That's all the mends I get, I have seen the same case tried at
Newbery the last sizes.
Well, things must slip and sleep, I will dissemble it,
Because my credit shall not lose her lustre,
But whilst I live, I'll neither love nor trust her.
I ha' done, I ha' done, I ha' done with her i'faith.

div.stage: Master paenitent once-ill-knocking within; enter a seruus.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Who's that knocks?

sp.speaker: Mast. Pae
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: What's your will sir?

sp.speaker: Ma. paenitent
sp.p: Is master Hargrave at home?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: No, newly gone from it sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Where's the gentlewoman his wife?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: My mistress is within sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: When came she in I pray?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Who my mistress? she was not out these two days to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: No? trust me I'd thought I'd seen her, I would request a word with her.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: I'll tell her sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: I thank you — it likes me worse and worse. —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why how now sir? 'twas desperately adventured, I little looked for you until the morrow.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: No? why what made you at my chamber then even now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I at your chamber?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Puh — dissemble not, come, come, you were there.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By my life you wrong me sir.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: First you're not ignorant what watch keeps o'er me, and for your chamber, as I live I know't not.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Burst into sorrow then, and griefs extremes, whilst I beat on this flesh.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What is't disturbs you sir? —

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Then was the devil in your likeness there.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.l: The very devil assumed thee formally,
That face, that voice, that gesture, that attire,
E'en as it sits on thee, not a pleat altered,
That beaver band, the colour of that periwig,
The farthingale above the navel, all;
As if the fashion were his own invention,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mercy defend me.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.l: To beguile me more.
The cunning succubus told me that meeting
Was wrought a purpose by much wit and art,
Wept to me, laid my vows before me, urged me,
Gave me the private marks of all our love,
Wood me in wanton and effeminate rhymes,
And sung and danced about me like a fairy,
And had not worthier cogitations blessed me,
Thy form and his enchantments had possessed me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What shall become of me my own thoughts doom me.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.l: Be honest; then the devil will ne'er assume thee,
He has no pleasure in that shape to abide,
Where these two sisters reign not, lust of pride;
He as much trembles at a constant mind
As looser flesh at him, — be not dismayed:
Spring souls for joy, his policies are betrayed;
Forgive me mistress Hargrave, on whose soul
The guilt hangs double,
My lust and thy enticement: both I challenge,
And therefore of due vengeance it appeared
To none but me to whom both sins inhered;
What knows the lecher when he clips his whore
Whether it be the devil his parts adore:
They're both so like, that in our natural sense,
I could discern no change nor difference.
No marvel then times should so stretch and turn
None for religion, all for pleasure burn.
Hot zeal into hot lust is now transformed,
Grace into painting, charity into clothes,
Faith into false hair, and put off as often,
There's nothing but our virtue knows a mean,
He that kept open house now keeps a quean.
He will keep open still, that he commends,
And there he keeps a table for his friends:
And she consumes more than her sire could hoard,
being more common than his house or board:
Live honest, and live happy, keep thy vows,
She's part a virgin whom but one man knows:
Embrace thy husband, and beside him none,
Having but one heart, give it but to one.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I vow it on my knees, with tears true bred
No man shall ever wrong my husband's bed.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Rise, I'm thy friend for ever.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.l: And I thine
For ever and ever, — let me embrace thee sir, whom I will
Love, even next unto my soul, and that's my wife,
Two dear rare gems this hour presents me with,
A wife that's modest, and a friend that's right,
Idle suspect and fear, now take your flight.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: A happy inward peace crown both your joys

sp.speaker: Harebrain.
sp.p: Thanks above utterance to you, — now? the news?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.l: Sir bounteous progress sir,
Invites you and my mistress to a feast,
On Tuesday next; his man attends without —

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.l: Return both with our willingness and thanks.
I will entreat you sir, to be my guest.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Who I sir.

sp.speaker: Harg.
sp.p: Faith you shall.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Well, I'll break strife.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.p: A friend's so rare, I'll sooner part from life.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit, the courtesan striving from him.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What so coy, so strict, come, come.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray change your opinion sir, I am not for that use.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I shall hear that I would not.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Sfoot this is strange, I've seldom seen a wench stand upon stricter points, life she will not endure to be courted, does she ere think to prosper? I'll ne'er believe that tree can bring forth fruit, that never bears a blossom, courtships a blossom, and often brings forth fruit in forty weeks; 'twere a mad part in me, now to turn over: if ever there were
any hope on't, 'tis at this instant, shall I be madder now than ever I have been? I'm in the way i'faith.
sp.l: Man's never at high height of madness full,
Until he love and prove a woman's gull;
I do protest in earnest I ne'er knew
At which end to begin to affect a woman,
Till this bewitching minute, I ne'er saw
sp.p: Face worth my object, till mine eye met hers, I should laugh and I were caught i'faith, I'll see her again that's certain, whate'er comes on't, by your favour ladies.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: You're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Know you the young gentlewoman that went in lately?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I have best cause to know her, I'm her mother sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: O in good time, I like the gentlewoman well, a pretty contrived beauty,

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Ay, nature has done her part sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: But she has one uncomely quality.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: What's that sir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sfoot she's afraid of a man.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: A lass, impute that to her bashful spirit, she's fearful of her honour.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Of her honour? slid I'm sure I cannot get her maiden head with breathing upon her, nor can she lose her honour in her tongue.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: True, and I have often told her so, but what would you have of a foolish virgin sir, a wilful virgin, I tell you sir, I need not have been in that solitary estate that I am, had she had grace and boldness to have put herself forward, always timorsome, always backward, ah that same peevish honour of hers, has undone her and me both good gentleman: the suitors, the jewels, the jointures that has been offered her, we had been made women for ever, but what was her fashion? she could not endure the sight of a man for sooth, but run and hole herself presently, so choice of her honour, I am persuaded, when ere she has husband, she will e'en be a precedent for all married wives, how to direct their actions, and their lives.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Have you not so much power with her, to command her presence.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: You shall see straight what I can do sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Would I might be hanged, if my love do not stretch to her deeper and deeper, those bashful maiden humours take me prisoner when their comes a restraint on't upon flesh, we are always most greedy upon't, and that makes your merchant's wife oftentimes pay so dear for a mouthful: give me a woman as she was made at first, simple of herself, without sophistication, like this wench, I cannot abide them when they have tricks, set speeches and artful entertainments, you shall have some so impudently aspected, they will outcry the forehead of a man, make him blush first, and talk him into silence, and this is counted manly in a woman, it may hold so, sure womanly it is not, no, if ere I love, or any thing move me,
'Twill be a woman's simple modesty.

div.stage: Enter mother bringing in strivingly the courtesan.

sp.speaker: Curte.
sp.p: Pray let me go, why mother what do you mean? I beseech you mother? is this your conquest now? great glory 'tis to overcome a poor and silly virgin.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: The wonder of our time sits in that brow,
I ne'er beheld a perfect man till now.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Thou childish thing, more bashful than thour't wise,
Why dost thou turn aside, and drown thine eyes?
Look fearful fool, there's no temptation near thee,
Art not ashamed that any flesh should fear thee,
sp.p: Why I durst pawn my life the gentleman means no other but honest and pure love to thee, how say you sir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: By my faith not I lady.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Hark you there? what think you now forsooth? what grieves your honour now?
Or what lascivious breath intends to rear
Against that maiden organ your chaste care?
Are you resolved now better of men's hearts?
Their faiths and their affections, with you none,
Or at most, few whose tongues and minds are one.
Repent you now of your opinion past,
Men love as purely as you can be chaste: to her yourself sir,
the ways broke before you, you have the easier passage,

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: Fear not, come; erect thy happy graces in thy look;
I am no curious wooer, but in faith
I love thee honourably.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.p: How mean you that sir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: 'Sfoot as one loves a woman for a wife,

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Has the gentleman answered you, trow?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: I do confess it truly to you both,
My estate is yet but sickly, but I've a grandsire
Will make me lord of thousands at his death.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: I know your grandsire well; she knows him better.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why then you know no fiction; my state then will be a long day's journey 'bove the waist wench.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Nay daughter he says true.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: And thou shalt often measure it in thy coach,
And with the wheels tract make a griddle for't.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Ah 'twill be a merry journey.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What is't a match, if't be clap hands and lips;

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: 'Tis done, there's witness on't.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why then mother I salute you.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Thanks sweet son; — son Folliwit, come hither, if I might counsel thee, we'll e'en take her while the good moods upon her, send for a priest, and clapped up within this hour.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: By my troth agreed mother.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Nor does her wealth consist all in her flesh,
Though beauty be enough wealth for a woman,
She brings a dowry of three hundred pound with her.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sfoot that will serve till my grandsire dies I warrant you, he'll drop away at fall a'th leaf, if ever he reach to all Hollantide I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: O yes son, he's a lusty old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Ah pox, he's given to women; he keeps a quean at this present.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Do not tell my wife on't.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: That were needless i'faith.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: He makes a great feast upon the eleventh of this month, Tuesday next, and you shall see players there, — I have one trick more to put upon him; my wife and yourself shall go thither before as my guests, and prove his entertainment, I'll meet you there at night, the jest will be here, that feast which he makes will, unknown to him serve fitly for our wedding dinner, we shall be royally furnished, and get some charges by't.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: An excellent course (I'faith) and a thrifty, why son, methinks you begin to thrive before you're married.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We shall thrive one day wench, and clep enough? Between our hopes there's but a grandsire's puff.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: So girl, here was a bird well caught.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: If ever, here: but what for's grandsire, 'twill scarce please him well.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Who covets fruit, never cares from whence it fell,
Thou'st wedded youth and strength, and wealth will fall:
Last thou'rt made honest.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And that's worth 'em all.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter busily sir bounteous progress for the feast.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Have a care blue-coats; bestir yourself master Gumwater, cast an eye into th' kitchen, o'erlook the knaves a little, every lack has his friend today, this cousin and that cousin puts in for a dish of meat, a man knows not till he make a feast how many varlets he feeds, acquaintances swarm in every corner, like flies at Bartholmew-tide that come up with drovers, 'sfoot I think they smell my kitchen seven mile about master Shortrod and his sweet bedfellow, you're very copiously welcome.

sp.speaker: Harebrain.
sp.p: Sir, here's an especial dear friend of ours, we were bold to make his way to your table.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Thanks for that boldness ever, good master
Shortrod, is this your friend sir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Both my wife's friend and mine sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why then compendiously sir, — you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: In octavo I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Excellently retorted i'faith, he's welcome for's wit; I have my sorts of salutes, and know how to place 'em courtly; walk in sweet gentlemen, walk in, there's a good fire it'h hall, you shall have my sweet company instantly.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.p: I good sir bounteous

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: You shall indeed gentlemen; how now, what news brings thee in stumbling now?

sp.speaker: Semus.
sp.p: There are certain players come to town sir, and desire to interlude before your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Players? by the mass they are welcome, they'll grace my entertainment well, but for certain players there thou liest boy; they were never more uncertain in their lives, now up and now down, they know not when to play, where to play, nor what to play, not when to play for fearful fools, where to play for Puritan fools, nor what to play for critical fools — go call 'em in, — how fitly the whoresons come upo'the feast, troth I was e'en wishing for 'em, — o welcome, welcome my friends.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: The month of may delights not in her flowers, more than we joy in that sweet sight of yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well acted a my credit, I perceive he's your best actor.

sp.speaker: Semus.
sp.p: He has greatest share sir; and may live of himself sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What what? put on your hat sir, pray put on; go too, wealth must be respected, let those that have least feathers stand bare; and whose men are you I pray? nay keep on your hat still.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We serve my lord Owemuch sir.

sp.speaker: S. Boun.
sp.p: My l. Owemuch, by my troth the welcom'st men alive give me all your hands at once, that honourable gentleman? he lay at my house in a robbery once, and took all quietly, went away cheerfully. I made a very good feast for him; I never saw a man of honour bear things bravelier away, serve my l. Owemuch? welcome i'faith: some bastard for my lords players, — where be you boys?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: They come along with the wagon sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good, good, and which is your politician amongst you? now i'faith he that works out restraints, makes best legs at court and has a suit made of purpose, for the company's business, which is he, come ▪ be not afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I am he sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Art thou he? give me thy hand, hark in thine ear, thou row lest too fast to gather so much moss as thy fellow there, champ upon that, ah, and what play shall we have my masters?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A pleasant witty comedy sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, a comedy in any case, that I and my guests may laugh a little, what's the name out?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: 'Tis called the slip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The slip? By my troth a pretty name, and a glib one: go all and slip into't, as fast as you can cover a table for the players. First take heed of a Lurcher, he cuts deep, he will eat up all from you. Some sherry for my lords players there. Sirrah, why this will be a true feast, a right mitre supper, a play and all, more lights — I called for light, here come in two are light enough for a whole house i'faith. Dare the thief look me i'th face? O impudent times! go too, dissemble it.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Bless you sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir bount.
sp.p: O welcome, welcome, thief, quean, and bawd, welcome all three.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Nay here's but two on's sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A my troth, I took her for a couple, I'd have sworn there had been two faces there.

sp.speaker: Mother ▪
sp.p: Not all under one hood sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun ▪
sp.p: Yes faith would I, to see mine eyes bear double.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: He make it hold sir, my daughter is a couple, she was married yesterday. Sir Boun. Buz.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Nay to no buzzard neither, a right hawk when ere you know him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Away, he cannot be but a rascal ▪ walk in walk in, bold guests, that come unsent for — post, I perceive how
my jewels went now, to grace her marriage.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Would you with me sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Ay, how happed it wench, you put the slip upon me,
Not three nights since? I name it gently to you,
I term it neither pilfer, cheat, nor shark.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You're past my reach.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I'm old and past your reach, very good; but you will not deny this I trust.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: With a safe conscience, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ye? give me thy hand, fare thee well, I have done with her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Give me your hand, sir, you ne'er yet begun with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Whew, whew? O audacious age.
She denies me and all, when on her fingers,
I spied the ruby sit, that does betray her,
And blushes for her fact, well there's a time for't,
For all's too little now for entertainment.
Feast, mirth, I harmony, and the play to boot.
A jovial season. How now, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Even upon readiness sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Keep you your hat on.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I have a suit to your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O cry you mercy, than you must stand bare.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We could do all to the life of action sir, both for the credit of your worship's house, and the grace of our comedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun ▪
sp.p: Cuds me, what else sir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: And for some defects (As the custom is) we would be bold to require your worship's assistance.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why with all my heart, what is't you want? speak.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: One's a chain for a justice's hat sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why here, here, here, here whoreson, will this serve your turn?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: What else lack you?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We should use a ring with a stone in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Nay whoop, I have given too many rings already, talk no more of rings I pray you, here, here, here, make this
jewel serve for once.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: O this will serve sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What have you all now?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: All now sir — one y time is brought i'th middle of the play, and I would desire your worship's watch time.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My watch, with all my heart, only give time a charge that he be not fiddling with it.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: You shall ne'er see that sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well now you are furnish sir, make haste away.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: E'en as fast as i can sir, — I'll set my fellows going first, they must have time and leisure, or they're dull else. He stay and speak a prologue, yet o'ertake 'em, I cannot have conscience i'faith to go away and speak never a word to 'em, my grandsire has given me three shares here, sure I'll do somewhat for 'em.

div.stage: Enter sir bounteous and all the guests.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: More lights, more stools, sit sit, the play begins.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Have you players here sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: We have 'em for you sir, fine nimble comedians, proper actors most of them.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: Whose men I pray you sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O ▪ there's their credit sir, they serve an honourable popular gentleman, yclept my lord Owemuch.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: My lord Owemuch, he was in Ireland lately.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O you ne'er knew any of the name but were great travellers,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How is the comedy called, sir bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Marry sir, the slip.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The slip?

sp.speaker: Sir Bou.
sp.p: Ay, and here the prologue begins to slip in upon's.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: 'Tis so indeed sir Boun.

sp.speaker: Folly ▪
sp.l: We sing of wandring knights, what them betide,
Who nor in one place, nor one thing abide,
they're here now, and anon no scouts can reach 'em
Being every man well horsed like a bold Beacham,
The play which we present, no fault shall mere
But one, you'll say 'tis short, we'll say 'tis sweet:
'Tis given much to dumb shows, which some praise,
And like the term, delights much in delays.
So to conclude, and give the name her due,
The play being called the slip, I vanish too.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Excellently well acted and a nimble conceit.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The prologues pretty i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: And went off well.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I that's the grace of all, when they go away well, ah -

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A my troth and I were not married, I could find in my heart to fall in love with that player now, and send for him to a supper; I know some i'th town that have done as much, and there took such a good conceit of their parts into'th twopenny room, that the actors have been found ith' morning in a less compass than their stage, though 'twere never so full of gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: But, passion of me, where be these knaves, will they not come away, methinks they stay very long.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: O you must bear a little sir, they have many shifts to run into.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Shifts call you 'em, they're horrible long things.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A pox of such fortune the plots betrayed:

All will come out, yonder they come taken upon suspicion, and brought back by a constable, I was accursed to hold society with such coxcombs, what's to be done? I shall be shamed for ever, my wife here and all, ah pox — by light happily thought upon, the chain ▪ invention stick to me this once, and fail me ever hereafter: so, so, —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Life I say, where be these players, o are you come, troth its time, I was e'en sending for you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How moodily he walks, what plays he trow?

sp.speaker: Sir Bou.
sp.p: A, justice upon my credit, I know by the chain there.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Unfortunate justice.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah — a — a —

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: In thy kin unfortunate.
Here comes thy nephew now upon suspicion,
Brought by a constable before thee, his vild associates with him,
But so disguised, none knows him but myself,
Twice have I set him free from officers fangs,
And for his sake, his fellows: let him look to't:
My conscience will permit but one wink more.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ye shall we take justice winking.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: For this time I have be thought a means to work thy
Freedom, though hazarding myself; should the law cease him,
Being kin to me, 'twould blemish much my name, no;
I'd rather lean to danger, than to shame.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun:
sp.p: A very explete justice.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Thank you good neighbours, let me alone with 'em now.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sfoot whose yonder?

sp.speaker: Ancient
sp.p: Dare he sit there?
2. Folly-wit.
3. Captain — puh —

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: How now constable what news with thee?

sp.speaker: Constable ▪
sp.p: May it please your worship sir, — here are a company of auspicious fellows.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: To me; puh — turn to'th justice you whoreson hobby horse, this is some new player now, they put all their fools to the constable's part still.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What's the matter constable, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I have nothing to say to your worship — they were all riding a horseback an't please your worship

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yet again: a pox of all asses still, they could not ride a foot unless 'twere in a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: The ostler told me they were all unstable fellows sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why sure the fellow's drunk.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
We spied that weakness in him long ago sir, your worship must bear with him, the man's much o'erseen, only in respect of his office we obeyed him, both to appear conformable to law, and clear of all offence: for I protest sir,
he found us but a horse back:

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What he did?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: As I have a soul, that's all, and all he can lay to us.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I'faith, you were not all riding away then.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: 'Sfoot, being a horseback sir, that must needs follow.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why true sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well said justice, he helps his kinsman well.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Why sirrah, do you use to bring gentlemen before us for riding away, what will you have 'em stand still when they're up, like Smug upo'the white horse yonder? are your wits steeped? He make you an example for all dizzy constables, how they abuse justice, here bind him tot his chair.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Ha, bind him ho?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: If you want cords, use garters.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Help, help, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: As fast as we can sir.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A gag will help all this, keep less noise you knave.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: O help, rescue the constable — o, o.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: Why la you who lets you now?
You may ride quietly, I'll see you to,
Take horse myself. I have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: O, — o — o —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha, by my troth the maddest piece of justice gentlemen, that ever was committed.

sp.speaker: Scort R.
sp.p: He be sworn for the madness on't sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I am deceived, if this prove not a merry comedy and a witty.

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: A lass poor constable, his mouth's open, and never a wife word.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Faith he speaks now e'en as many as he has done, he seems wisest when he gapes and says nothing, ha ha; — he turns and tells his tale to me like an ass, what have I to do with their riding away, they may ride for me, thou whoreson coxcomb then; nay thou art well enough served i'faith,

sp.speaker: Mast. paenitent
sp.p: But what follows all this while sir, methinks some should pass by before this time, and pity the constable.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Byth' mass and you say true sir, — go sirrah, step in, I think they have forgotten themselves, call the knaves away they're in a wood I believe. —

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hank, the constable says I, they're in a wood, — ha, ha, —

sp.speaker: Nub.
sp.p: He thinks long of the time sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now? when come they?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A lass an't please your worship, there's not one of them to be found sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Short. R.
sp.p: What says the fellow?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Neither horse nor man sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Body of me thou liest.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Not a hair of either sir.

sp.speaker: Short. R.
sp.p: How now sir bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Cheated and defeated, ungag that rascal, I'll hang him for's fellows, I'll make him bring 'em out.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Did not I tell your worship this before, brought 'em before you for suspected persons, hayd 'em at towns end upon warning given, made signs that my very jaw bone aches, your worship would not hear me, called me ass, saving your worship's presence laughed at me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I begin to taste it.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Give me leave, give me leave, why art not thou the constable it'h comedy?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Ith' comedy? why I am the constable i'th common wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: I am gulled i'faith, I am gulled, when wast thou chose?

sp.speaker: Consta ▪
sp.p: On Thursday last sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: A pox go wi't, there't goes.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: I seldom heard jest match it.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Nor I i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Gentlemen shall I entreat a courtesy?

sp.speaker: Short ▪
sp.p: What is't sir?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Do not laugh at me seven year hence.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: We should betray and laugh at our own folly then, for of my troth none here but was deceived in't.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Faith that's some comfort yet, ha, ha, it was featly carried, troth I commend their wits, before our faces, make us asses while we sit still, and only laugh at ourselves.

sp.speaker: M. peni.
sp.p: Faith they were some counterfeit rogues sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Why they confess so much themselves, they said they'd play the slip, they should be men of their words, I hope the justice will have more conscience i'faith, then to carry away a chain of a hundred mark of that fashion.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: I by my troth sir, besides a jewel, and a jewel's fellow, a good fair watch that hung about my neck sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Sfoot what did you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: methinks my lord Owemuch's players should not scorn me so i'faith they will come and bring all again I know, push they will i'faith, but a jest certainly.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit in his own shape, and all the rest,

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Pray grandsire give me your blessing?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Who? Son Folliwit?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: This shows like kneeling after the play, I praying for my lord Owemuch and his good countess, our honourable lady and mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Rise richer by a blessing, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Thanks good grandsire, I was bold to bring those gentlemen my friends.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: They're all welcome, salute you that side, and I'll welcome this side. Sir to begin with you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Master Folly-wit.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I am glad 'tis our fortune so happily to meet sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Nay then you know me not sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sweet mistress Harebrain.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: You cannot be too bold sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Our marriage known?

sp.speaker: Curte.
sp.p: Not a word yet.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: The better.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p:
Faith son would you had come sooner with these
gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why grandsire?

sp.speaker: S. Bo.
sp.p: We had a play here.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A play sir, no.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Yes faith, a pox a'th author.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Bless us all, why were they such vild ones sir?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: I am sure villainous ones sir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Some raw-simple fools.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Nay byth' mass these were enough for the evish knaves.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: Which way came you gentlemen, you could not choose but meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We met a company with hampers after 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: O those were they, those were they, a pox hamper 'em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Bless us all again.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: They have hampered me finely sirrah.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: How sir.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.p: How sir, I lent the rascals properties to furnish out their play, a chain, a jewel, and a watch, and they watched their time, and rid quite away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Are they such creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hark, hark gentlemen, by this light the watch rings alarum in his pocket, there's my watch come again, or the very cousin german to't, whose is't, whose is't? by'th mass 'tis he, hast thou one son? prithee bestow it upon thy grandsire, I now look for mine again i'faith, nay come with a good will or not at all. I'll give thee a better thing a piece, a piece gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Great or small,

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: At once I have drawn chain, jewel, watch and all.

sp.speaker: Mast. penit.
sp.p: By my faith you have a fortunate hand sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Nay all to come at once.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A vengeance of this foolery.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Have I scape the constable to be brought in by the watch?

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.p: O destiny, have I married a thief mother?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Comfort thyself, thou art before hand with him daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why son, why gentlemen, how long have you been my lord Owemuch his servants i'faith?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Faith grandsire, shall I be true to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I think 'tis time, thoust been a thief already.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I knowing the day of your feast, and the natural inclination you have to pleasure and pastime, presumed upon your patience for a jest as well to prolong your days as —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Whoop, why then you took my chain along with you to prolong my days did you?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Not so neither sir and that you may be seriously assured of my hereafter stableness of life, I have taken another course.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Took a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A wife? 'sfoot, what is she for a fool would marry thee a madman? when was the wedding kept in bedlam?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: She's both a gentlewoman and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Stop there, stop there, would I might see her.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: You have your wish, she's here.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha, this makes amends for all.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Captain do you hear? is she your wife in earnest?

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nothing but pity you sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Speak son is't true?
Can you gull us, and let a quean gull you.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Courtesan
sp.l: What I have been is past, be that forgiven,
And have a soul true both to thee and heaven.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Is't come about, tricks are repaid I see.

sp.speaker: Sir bo.
sp.l: The best is sirrah you pledge none but me
And since I drink the top, take her and hark,
I spice the bottom with a thousand mark.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.l: By my troth, she is as good a cup of nectar, as any
Bachelor needs to sip at.
Tut give me gold, it makes amends for vice,
Maids without coin, are candles without spice.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Come gentlemen tooth feast, let not time waste,
We have pleased our ear, now let us please our taste
Who lives by cunning mark it, his fates cast,
When he has gulled all, then is himself the last.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
